opener.dateline:
United States Commercial Agency,
St Paul de Loanda, 24th August 1877.

div1.p: I have the honor to report to the Department the arrival at this Port of the distinguished African traveller Henry M. Stanley.

He reached here on the 21st inst. on board the Portuguese Man of War "Rio Tamega" from Cabenda where he arrived on the 11th idem, having been successful in the discovery of the source of the River Congo which, he proves without doubt, to be a continuation of the Lualaba. He has traveled a country hitherto unknown and I am sure his success will be highly appreciated by every nation. He had to fight his way in several places the natives
natives being in some parts extremely unfriendly not even allowing him to trade for food, but considering he and his men more as wild animals, fit only to be shot at, than human beings. He passed 57 Cataracts or Rapids above which the River Congo is navigable for vessels of large size for 2000 miles. After passing all the falls to below Yellala, and many of his men being sick and dispirited, he struck across country for 5 days and came out at Boma where, he first met English and Portuguese Traders. From Boma he proceeded to Cabenda in a steamer belonging to one of the English houses at which place he was received on board the "Rio Tamega". He brings with him 115 natives being all that are left of about
about 350 he started with, many having been lost in the Cataracts. The young Englishman Frank Pocock who had accompanied him all this way was also drowned in passing one of the Cataracts only some 2 months before their arrival at Boma. It was at a place called Nyangme that he first learnt of Captn Cameron's having accompanied Portuguese Traders to the West Coast.
Mr Stanley speaks in the very highest terms of gratitude for the kind treatment which he and his men received from the Commander and Officers of the "Rio Tamega".

Since his arrival here he has been treated with the greatest of kindness by the Portuguese and is staying at present
present with Major Serpa Pinto and Mr. Brito Capello who are also about to start for the interior on a scientific expedition.
Governor Albuquerque is doing everything in his power to assist Mr Stanley, all his men being kept as guests of the Government.

Enclosed I hand a litteral translation of an official despatch received from His Excellency The Governor congratulating me as representative of the American Nation on the highly successful termination of the arduous journey just accomplished by her distinguished explorer and offering all the assistance in his power. Herewith I send copy of my reply.
I have telegraphed the news of Mr Stanley's arrival to the Consul at Liverpool to be forwarded to the Department.

closer.salute:
I have the honor
to be,
Your most obedt Servt,

Robt S Newton
